tgt_text.104: Such are some of the more famous editions of the whole of Sophocles.
tgt_text.105: Of separate plays there have been almost in­ numerable editors, some few only of whose names can here be given.
tgt_text.106: Among the best known are Lobeck, Donaldson, Monk, Elmsley, Burges, Matthiæ, Campbell and Abbott, Kennedy, etc., etc.
tgt_text.107: Of translations in verse, those of Francklin, Dale, Plumptre, Campbell, and Whitelaw are the most meritorious;
tgt_text.108: but there is as yet not a single complete prose version in English deserving of mention.
tgt_text.109: The MSS. of Sophocles are numerous, but very few con­ tain all the seven extant plays.(i.)
tgt_text.110: The oldest and best is the Laurentianus or Mediceus, which contains all the plays, together with those of Æschylus and the " Argonautica " of Apollonius Rho­ dius.
tgt_text.111: It belongs to the tenth or eleventh century, and is known by the letters L or M. Cobet was of opinion that all other MSS.
tgt_text.112: were derived from this, but this view is not generally held.(ii.)
tgt_text.113: A Parisinus MS., known as A, contains all the seven plays, with valuable marginal glosses;
tgt_text.115: A Parisinus MS., known as T, containing the seven plays;
tgt_text.117: some readings occur in it which are not found elsewhere.(iv.)
tgt_text.118: A Parisinus MS., known as B, said to be of high authority;
tgt_text.119: possibly V (the Vaticanus) was copied from it, as it exhibits many resemblances;
tgt_text.120: each of these contains four plays only.
tgt_text.121: A fuller discussion of this subject may be found in Blaydes Index to the MSS., which is prefixed to his edition.
tgt_text.122: As with many another great poet, whose masterpieces remain the wonder of all succeeding ages, very little is known of the personal life of Sophocles;
tgt_text.123: but this dearth of detail is less to be regretted in the case of a writer, respect­ ing whose age we have ample evidence.
tgt_text.124: The poet is, to a great extent, the product of his age, and, if we know some­ thing of his environment, we shall be fairly qualified to re­ construct his life even from rather scanty materials.
tgt_text.125: Now the long life of Sophocles, extending from B.C. 496 or 5 to 406 or 5, is coincident with scenes the most stirring and names the most illustrious in the whole period of Athenian, if not of Greek, history.
tgt_text.126: Thus his boyhood would have been passed amid the excite­ ment of the Persian wars, and his imagination fired by the wonderful development of Athens, immediately the danger of foreign invasion was over.
tgt_text.127: He would have witnessed, in his manhood, the rapid steps by which Athens mounted to a position of power and splendour never attained by any Greek state before or after;
tgt_text.128: while, in his later years, the various scenes of the Peloponnesian war, that great struggle for supremacy between Athens and Sparta, unfolded them­ selves one by one before his eyes.
tgt_text.129: Death came to him at a singularly fortunate moment.
tgt_text.130: The battle of Arginusæ had restored to Athens some of her old prestige, and, though it was but a momentary success, the old poet did not live to see all hope finally extinguished by the disastrous defeat at Ægospotami.
tgt_text.131: What a list of great names, other than those of general and statesman, crowds these ninety years!
tgt_text.133: Simonides and Pindar, the lyric poets;
tgt_text.136: Aristophanes, greatest of all comic poets;
tgt_text.138: sculptors like Phidias, Polycleitus, and Myron;
tgt_text.140: deep thinkers like Socrates and the Sophists Hippias, Prodicus, and Gorgias.
tgt_text.141: And these are only a few of the great men of that age, with many of whom so popular a poet as Sophocles was doubtless on friendly terms.
tgt_text.142: Little wonder then that his plays, the outcome as they were of a period so intellectually rich, exhibit that perfect workmanship and marvellous finish that have been the delight and despair of all succeeding dramatists.
tgt_text.143: Passing from the poet's surroundings to the actual facts of his personal life, we find not only that our authorities are extremely scanty, but also that much of what they tell us is little better than the doubtful gossip which ever pursues the steps of those who are something different from the mass.
tgt_text.144: An anonymous life of the poet, of uncertain date, a brief notice in Suidas, with certain incidental remarks scattered through the works of Athenæus, most garrulous of story-tellers, or gleaned from the pages of the accom­ plished Plutarch, are our main sources for the little that is related about Sophocles.
tgt_text.145: He was born in B.C. 496 or 5, at Colonus, an Attic deme of great natural beauty on the banks of the Cephissus, within easy walking distance of Athens.
tgt_text.146: His father, Sophilus or Sophillus by name, must have been a man of some means, though his exact employment is unknown ;
tgt_text.147: for he gave his son the very best education then obtainable.
tgt_text.148: And such skill did the son acquire in music, dancing, and gymnastics, and so naturally graceful was his figure, that he was chosen in B.C. 480 to lead the chorus of young Athenians in the triumphal dance round the trophy erected after the victory at Salamis.
tgt_text.149: Twelve years later comes a great epoch in his life.
tgt_text.150: It was the spring festival of the Dionysia, and Sophocles had entered the lists with the veteran Æschylus.
tgt_text.151: Public opinion was divided, and it was only after considerable delay that the Archon Eponymus, whose duty it was to select by lot the judges in the dramatic contest, hit upon the happy expedient of calling upon the general, Cimon, and his colleagues, who had just returned from Scyros with the bones of the hero Theseus, to take the oath and decide between the two.
tgt_text.152: They awarded the first prize to Sophocles, the second to Æschylus.
tgt_text.153: According to Plutarch, the old poet was so mortified at his defeat that he retired to Sicily;
tgt_text.154: but Aristophanes, in the “Frogs," depicts such a friendly feeling as subsisting between the two poets, that we might fairly surmise other reasons for the retirement of Æschylus from Athens.
tgt_text.155: What the plays were on this memorable occasion, we are not told.
tgt_text.156: Critics, who have gone deeply into the question, believe that Sophocles exhibited the " Triptolemus," a play dealing with the Eleusinian mysteries;
tgt_text.157: but this is little more than guess­ work.
tgt_text.158: From the year B.C. 468 till his death, Sophocles enjoyed unshaken popularity, gaining no less than eighteen or twenty first prizes, and, even when defeated, never falling below the second place, and that, too, with such a formidable rival as Euripides, who began exhibiting in B.C. 455, a year after the death of Æschylus, and gained the first prize in B.C. 441, the very year before Sophocles made such a deep impression with his “Antigone."
tgt_text.159: It is said that, by way of compliment to the author of this play, Sophocles was chosen in that year, with Pericles and eight other generals, for the subduing of Samos.
tgt_text.160: He does not seem, however, to have evinced any taste for military service;
tgt_text.161: and Pericles is reported by Athenæus to have said of him, that he was a good poet, but a bad general.
tgt_text.162: Not only, then, must Sophocles have .
tgt_text.163: been brought into close contact with the greatest statesmen of the day, but it was also during this expedition, if we may credit our authorities, that he made the acquaintance of Herodotus, the father of historians.
tgt_text.164: That a close friendship did spring up between the two can scarcely be doubted, for there is a fragment of a hymn to Herodotus written by Sophocles;
tgt_text.165: and further, the striking parallelisms in their works suggest that one of them was more deeply influenced by the other than would have been the case, probably, if one had merely been familiar with the other's writings.
tgt_text.166: Of the latter part of the poet's life we have very few details.
tgt_text.167: It was the period of his greatest poetical activity, and perhaps for that very reason the least marked by any stirring incident.
tgt_text.168: To these later years, from B.C. 440 onwards, belong all his extant dramas.
tgt_text.169: Still, it would be unjust to suppose that he shirked his duties to the state.
tgt_text.170: On the contrary, we find among the ten πρόβουλοι, a committee appointed to provide for the public safety after the news of the disaster in Sicily, the name of Sophocles.
tgt_text.171: If this was the poet, which some have doubted, he would have been performing a somewhat arduous duty for his country at a very critical time and at a very advanced age.
tgt_text.172: Towards the close of his life, his peace was temporarily disturbed by the unfilial conduct of his elder son.
tgt_text.175: by his first wife he had a son Iophon ;
tgt_text.178: Now Ariston had a son called Sophocles, for whom the old poet conceived so deep an affection, that Iophon suspected he would leave him an undue portion of his property.
tgt_text.179: Accordingly he brought his father before a jury of his tribe, charging him with senile imbecility and consequent incapacity to manage his estate,-a charge from which the old poet triumphantly cleared himself by reciting to his judges that magnificent eulogy on his native place which is contained in the " CEdipus at Colonus."
tgt_text.181: how the judges rose in a body and escorted the poet to his home after severely rebuking his son.
tgt_text.182: This is all that we really know of the life of Sophocles.
tgt_text.183: Neither the date or manner of his death are precisely ascertained, but it probably took place either in B.C. 406 or 5, and as this would bring the poet to his ninetieth year, we shall not, perhaps, be very far wrong in attributing it rather to natural decay than to any of the more fanciful causes which later writers, with an eye to realistic effect, have delighted to invent.
tgt_text.185: full of years and full of honour, blest in his death as in his life, having seen his country in her triumph, and being spared the grief of her humiliation;
tgt_text.186: retaining his faculties to the end, and leaving behind him, if ever poet did, κτῆμα ἐς ἀεὶ μᾶλλον ἢ ἀγώνισμα ἐς τὸ παραχοῆμα ἀκούειν.
tgt_text.187: The deep respect with which the memory of Sophocles was treated by Phrynichus and Aristophanes is no small evidence of his universal and well-deserved popularity;
tgt_text.188: both publicly made honourable allusion to him in the year following his death.
tgt_text.189: Why he was so popular is best explained, perhaps, by the epithet εὒκολος, "a man of easy temper," which Aristophanes so emphatically applies to him.
tgt_text.190: In him, too, Nature and training had combined to produce almost the Greek ideal of a man,—a beautiful mind in a beautiful body,-and this happy combination, together with his even temperament, no doubt made it easy for him to gain many friends and make few enemies.
tgt_text.191: If it be worth noticing a charge afterwards brought against him, that he was too much addicted to sensual pleasures, a sufficient answer may be found to it in the following sentence of Mr. John Addington Symonds:
tgt_text.192: "That a poet, distinguished for his physical beauty, should refrain from sensual enjoyments in the flower of his age, is not a Greek, but a Christian notion.
tgt_text.193: Such abstinence would have indicated in Sophocles mere want of inclination."
tgt_text.194: That he was no lifelong slave to his passions is proved by the passage in the "Republic" of Plato (p. 329), where Cephalus is telling Socrates how Sophocles, in his old age, rejoiced to have escaped from carnal pleasure as from " a frantic and savage master."
tgt_text.195: These are scarcely the words of a sensualist.
tgt_text.196: A second charge brought against him is really scarcely better supported.
tgt_text.197: On a passage in the " Peace " of Aristo­ phanes (11. 696-700), some have built up a theory that Sophocles, in his old age, turned a second Simonides in his greed for gain.
tgt_text.198: It is, of course, conceivable, as these critics urge, that he may have found himself forced to work for pay in order to meet his expenses;
tgt_text.199: but the remark of Aristophanes is far more probably a piece of banter, not seriously meant;
tgt_text.200: and even were it otherwise, the evidence is far too slight to convict Sophocles of miserly avarice.
tgt_text.201: The feeling against taking money for intellectual work was undoubtedly strong in Greece;
tgt_text.202: this was one of the chief causes of prejudice against the Sophists, that they taught for pay;
tgt_text.203: and, this being so, we can scarcely believe that, had Sophocles offended in this respect, he would have retained his popularity to the end of his life, or that his country­ men would have paid him such extravagant honours after his death as to institute a solemn yearly sacrifice to his memory.
tgt_text.204: One hundred and thirty plays were anciently ascribed to him;
tgt_text.205: of these, seventeen were regarded as spurious by Aristophanes the critic of Byzantium ;
tgt_text.206: there were also other works that passed under his name.
tgt_text.207: Seven tragedies alone are extant, with a great number of fragments, mostly very short and unimportant.
tgt_text.208: These seven were generally sup­ posed to have been the poet's best work,-the "Trachiniæ,” perhaps, excepted, in which there are not wanting traces of that inequality of composition noticed by ancient critics.
tgt_text.209: Too little is known about the order of their production for any dates to be given, save in the case of the "Antigone," which is thought to have appeared in B.C. 440, and of the " Philoctetes," which is assigned to the year B.C. 409.
tgt_text.210: Both of these won the first prize.
tgt_text.211: The “ Œdipus at Colonus" was brought out posthumously by Iophon, but is not on that account to be necessarily re­ garded as a work of the poet's last years ;
tgt_text.212: indeed, were it not that this play shows signs of interpolations,-the work of a later and less skilful hand,-it would scarcely be too much to say that it is as fine as any, if not the finest, of all his extant works.
tgt_text.213: Several important changes are attributed to Sophocles in the form and mechanism of the drama.
tgt_text.214: Thus, by the addition of a third actor, he immensely enlarged the scope of the dramatic action.
tgt_text.215: He increased the number of the Chorus from twelve to fifteen, but gave it a more subordinate part in the action of the play, while he reduced the number and length of the choral odes.
tgt_text.216: He is also said to have introduced scene-painting.
tgt_text.217: But the most important of his innovations was the abandonment of the trilogistic form.
tgt_text.218: Tragic trilogies at first dealt with three portions of the same story;
tgt_text.219: Sophocles is said to have contended with three tragedies wholly unconnected in plot, or even with one tragedy alone, instead of the old tetralogy, consisting of three connected tragedies, followed by a Satyric drama.
tgt_text.220: Lastly, owing to the weakness of his voice, Sophocles broke through the custom of the poet appearing himself in character, except, perhaps, in a few slight parts, where this defect would not prove any serious obstacle.
tgt_text.221: Any discussion of the style and language of Sophocles must be omitted here as a subject requiring too lengthy treatment for the limits of an introductory essay.
tgt_text.222: Students interested in the subject will do well to refer to Professor Campbell's essay, to Mr. Symonds' article on Sophocles in his Greek Poets," or to Mahaffy's History of Greek Classical Literature," in any of which will be found an adequate account of him, on whom the ancients conferred the name of " the Attic bee " for the sweetness of his style.
tgt_text.224: TEIRESIAS, led in by a boy.
tgt_text.226: CHORUS OF THEBAN ELDERS.SCENE.-Before the royal palace at Thebes.
tgt_text.227: THE great Theban legend, of which the fortunes of Œdipus form a part, was so well known to an Athenian audience, that Sophocles did not feel called upon to preface his play with any account of the previous history of his hero.
tgt_text.228: To a modern reader, however, of the poet's great masterpiece some few intro­ ductory remarks are almost indispensable for a full and ready comprehension of the plot;
tgt_text.229: and it is to supply this want that the following brief outline of the story is given.
tgt_text.230: Laius, King of Thebes, being childless, had consulted Apollo at Delphi as to his hopes of issue, and the god had told him, that he should beget a son, but lose his life by that son's hand.
tgt_text.231: Accordingly, when Jocasta, the queen, gave birth to a son, his father, to avoid this danger, gave the babe to a shepherd to expose on Mount Cithaeron, after first maiming the child by boring a hole through its feet and so fastening them together.
tgt_text.232: The shepherd, however, touched with pity, refrained from actually killing the child, and gave it instead to another herds­ man, in the service of Polybus, King of Corinth.
tgt_text.233: This man took the child to Corinth, where Polybus and his wife Merope, being childless, adopted it as their own ;
tgt_text.234: and as such it was reputed, until, one day at a banquet, a man, heated with wine, taunted the young prince with being no true son of the royal house.
tgt_text.235: Upon this Œdipus-such being the name he had re­ ceived in consequence of the wounds in his feet-questioned his supposed parents, and was partly reassured ;
tgt_text.236: still, to set his own mind completely at rest, he started off secretly to consult the oracle of Delphi and learn the story of his birth.
tgt_text.237: Apollo gave him, however, no clear answer on this point, but thrilled him with amazement and horror by foretelling that he should murder his own father, marry his mother, and beget unnatural offspring.
tgt_text.238: His resolve is taken at once ;
tgt_text.239: he will never see Corinth and his parents any more.
tgt_text.240: Accordingly he turns his steps towards Thebes, taking the road through Phocis to Bœotia.
tgt_text.241: On his way, he comes to a narrow pass where three roads meet;
tgt_text.242: a chariot, carrying one man attended by a small retinue, is coming in the opposite direction ;
tgt_text.243: there is no room for the way­ farer on the narrow track, and he is insolently bidden to stand aside ;
tgt_text.244: a quarrel ensues, in which CEdipus kills the occupant of the chariot and all his followers, save one who escapes and carries tidings to Thebes, that robbers have slain the king and all his retinue save himself on the way from Delphi.
tgt_text.245: Shortly afterwards, it may be surmised, CEdipus arrives at Thebes, where he finds the city, already distracted by the ravages of the Sphinx,-a monster sent by Hera to persecute the old home of her rival Semele,—plunged into utter helplessness and despair by the loss of its king.
tgt_text.246: The distress of the Thebans is too great even to allow them to make any lengthy inquiry into their monarch's murder.
tgt_text.247: Daily the Sphinx is propounding her dark riddle and exacting a life for every failure to solve it.
tgt_text.248: CEdipus succeeds, where others have failed ;
tgt_text.249: the Sphinx kills herself in vexation ;
tgt_text.251: and the citizens, in gratitude, make the newcomer king, and give him to wife Jocasta, the late king's widow.
tgt_text.252: Upon this the herdsman, recognizing in his new master the man who had slain Laius at the pass in Phocis, but not daring now to publish the knowledge, obtains the queen's permission to leave the neighbourhood of the court, without exciting any suspicion.
tgt_text.253: Some years elapse before anything occurs to mar the happi­ ness of the new king ;
tgt_text.254: he has children by his wife, two sons and two daughters ;
tgt_text.255: his subjects are devoted to him, and the land has rest and is prosperous.
tgt_text.256: Suddenly and without any apparent reason a fierce pestilence swoops on the city ;
tgt_text.257: there is a murrain on man and beast, and the earth will not yield her increase.
tgt_text.258: All in their dire affliction turn to the great CEdipus for succour ;
tgt_text.259: he has saved them before, and he will not fail them in their present need.
tgt_text.260: It is this graphic point which Sophocles has seized for the opening of his play.
tgt_text.261: A body of suppliants, young and old to­ gether, with the priest of Zeus for their spokesman, have ranged themselves round the palace-altar to crave the king's assistance.
tgt_text.262: In answer to his fatherly and sympathetic inquiries, they tell him, through their spokesman, of the wide-spread suffering;
tgt_text.263: adding that, next to the gods, they deem him most competent to devise a remedy (11. I-57).
tgt_text.264: CEdipus assures them of his sympathy ;
tgt_text.265: what they suffer is intensified in his case ;
tgt_text.266: all he can do, he will;
tgt_text.267: indeed he has already sent Creon, his wife's brother, to ask Apollo at Delphi what must be done.
tgt_text.268: He is still expressing surprise at Creon's long absence, when the approach of the latter is announced (11. 58-81).
tgt_text.269: The answer Creon brings is, that the murderer of Laius must be found and expelled from the land, which is still harbouring him.
tgt_text.270: Difficult as it now is to find a clue after the lapse of years, CEdipus at once confidently declares that he will unravel the matter from the very beginning ;
tgt_text.271: and, with this promise, he dismisses the suppliants, and summons his subjects to meet him forthwith for the purpose of a general in­ quiry.
tgt_text.273: As CEdipus quits the stage, the Chorus, consisting of Theban elders, chant an ode invoking all kindly deities to protect their city against Ares, the dealer of death and pestilence.
tgt_text.274: (11. 151-215.)CEdipus re-enters, and bids all who know anything of the murder of Laius speak, while he pronounces a solemn curse on the guilty wretch, and on all who harbour him.
tgt_text.275: At the same time, he declares his intention of leaving nothing untried to bring home the crime to the murderer.
tgt_text.277: The Chorus suggest that the best course will be to summon the prophet Teiresias ;
tgt_text.278: to which CEdipus rejoins, that he has already done so ;
tgt_text.279: and, as they are still speaking, the aged pro­ phet is led in (11. 275-299).
tgt_text.280: The king entreats him to use his best skill to rescue the State ;
tgt_text.281: but Teiresias is very reluctant to speak ;
tgt_text.282: so much so that CEdipus is wroth with him and rebukes him for his selfishness in concealing knowledge, which would benefit the community ;
tgt_text.283: even going so far as to accuse the old man of complicity in the crime.
tgt_text.284: Then, at last, Teiresias speaks and declares that the denier of the land is no other than CEdipus himself, who is not only a murderer, but is guilty of yet deeper shame.
tgt_text.285: At this unexpected accusation, CEdipus loses all self- control and taunts the prophet with blindness in his art as in his eyes (11. 300-377).
tgt_text.286: Next he accuses Creon of having suborned the seer, in order to serve his own ambitious schemes to gain the throne. "
tgt_text.287: This prophet," he exclaims, " is a mere charlatan.
tgt_text.288: Why, when the Sphinx was here, had he no good advice to offer?
tgt_text.289: Well, he shall rue his villainy."
tgt_text.291: but the quarrel has become too heated to end here, and Teiresias in impressive language pronounces on CEdipus his coming doom, and hints at the awful abyss of misery in which he will soon be plunged, when the truth is all revealed (11. 378- 428).
tgt_text.292: CEdipus calls upon his servants to remove this prophet of evil from his sight ;
tgt_text.293: but, before the seer quits the stage, he repeats his prophecies and bids the king take heed of them and judge of his skill by the result.
tgt_text.295: The Chorus have heard what the prophet says, but they will not yet believe that CEdipus is guilty.
tgt_text.298: doubtless he is already a wan­ derer in secret places ;
tgt_text.299: it cannot surely be Œdipus who has done the deed ;
tgt_text.300: the prophet is mortal after all, and may be wrong ;
tgt_text.301: CEdipus has ever served the State;
tgt_text.302: it is impossible to believe in his guilt.
tgt_text.304: Meantime Creon, having heard of the vile insinuations against his loyalty, comes in excitedly to learn why such baseless charges have been brought.
tgt_text.305: CEdipus, however, now accuses him to his face, and refuses to listen, when Creon attempts to clear himself and prove the unreasonableness of the king's suspicions (11. 512-615.)
tgt_text.306: The Chorus endeavour to mediate,--but in vain ;
tgt_text.307: and the quarrel is becoming every moment more bitter, when Jocasta enters and bids Creon depart, and her husband forbear.
tgt_text.308: Creon imprecates a curse upon himself, if he has done aught treason­ able, and then leaves the stage, though CEdipus is still far from pacified by the queen's intervention.
tgt_text.310: Then follows a long conversation between CEdipus and Jocasta.
tgt_text.311: CEdipus relates what Teiresias has predicted ;
tgt_text.312: whereupon Jocasta cuts him short, by saying that little faith is to be put in oracles, instancing the case of Laius, of whom it was foretold,—if not by Apollo, at least by his ministers,-that he should die by the hand of his own son ;
tgt_text.313: and yet that could not have happened, for the child was exposed on Cithaeron, when three days old;
tgt_text.314: while Laius met his death by the hand of robbers, at a place where three roads met.
tgt_text.316: The mention of the spot, where Laius fell, startles (Edipus ;
tgt_text.317: he asks for a description of the murdered man, and every known detail of the tragedy.
tgt_text.318: Everything tallies with his own fore­ bodings ;
tgt_text.319: Laius must have been the very man he killed himself, on his way from Delphi years ago;
tgt_text.320: in which case he has put himself beneath a curse, and is of all men most miserable. "
tgt_text.321: But who brought the tidings of the disaster to Thebes ?" "
tgt_text.322: It was a servant," answers Jocasta, " the sole survivor who came home." " Then would I could see him ! " (11, 726-765).

tgt_text.1789: BETWEEN the close of the “CEdipus the King" and the opening of the " CEdipus at Colonus ” a considerable period is supposed to have elapsed.
tgt_text.1790: CEdipus, after the fearful disclosures made in the earlier play, had remained at Thebes, while Creon administered the government.
tgt_text.1791: By degrees, the blinded sufferer grew recon­ ciled to his changed circumstances, and no longer felt any wish to fly from the scene of his misfortunes;
tgt_text.1792: but, as time went on, the Thebans came to believe that they were harbouring a pollu­ tion, and CEdipus was expelled.
tgt_text.1793: His sons make no effort to save him ;
tgt_text.1794: only his daughters remain loyal,–Antigone going forth to share his wanderings, Ismene staying in Thebes to watch the course of events and help her father, as occasion may offer.
tgt_text.1795: But, one day, came an oracle to Thebes, which said that on CEdipus alone depended the welfare of the city ;
tgt_text.1796: and thus it became of paramount importance that the Thebans should induce the old wanderer to return.
tgt_text.1797: Meantime, however, his two sons have quarrelled.
tgt_text.1798: Polyneices, the elder, has been driven from his native land by his brother Eteocles, and has taken refuge at Argos, where he has married the daughter of the king ;
tgt_text.1799: with the aid of the latter and his allies, he is bent on leading an expedi­ tion to Thebes, to extort submission from his brother,-the one thing essential to success being the presence of CEdipus.
tgt_text.1800: Such, very briefly, are the events which fill the interval between the two plays.
tgt_text.1801: The scene of the " CEdipus at Colonus " lies be­ fore a grove of the Eumenides at Colonus, to which the wanderer has made his way, guided by his daughter Antigone.
tgt_text.1802: He is in search of some resting-place, and is asking his child what spot they have reached.
tgt_text.1803: Scarcely has he seated himself, after learning that they are close to Athens, when a native of the place enters and bids him depart and trespass not on holy ground.
tgt_text.1804: On learning that he has reached a grove of the Awful God­ desses," CEdipus declines to move, remembering the words of Apollo, that when he reached such a spot, he should at last find rest.
tgt_text.1805: At his request, the stranger, who has accosted him, goes to fetch Theseus, the king of the land ;
tgt_text.1806: and, on his departure, Œdipus, after offering up a prayer to the Eumenides, withdraws further into the sacred grove, as certain elders of Colonus make their appearance.
tgt_text.1808: They have come to see who this rash intruder can be.
tgt_text.1809: As they are still searching for him, CEdipus comes slowly forward from his place of concealment.
tgt_text.1810: His appearance calls forth an expression of horror, and once more he is bidden to leave the holy ground he has invaded.
tgt_text.1811: He hesitates, but yields at last under a promise of protection from the elders of Colonus, and takes a seat, as directed by them, on a ledge of rock near the outskirts of the grove.
tgt_text.1813: As soon as he is seated, the Chorus ask him who he is and whence he comes.
tgt_text.1814: Word by word, the awful truth is wrested from his unwilling lips, but at the mention of his name the Chorus raise a cry of execration, and are half inclined to break their promise and send him forth from the land ;
tgt_text.1815: the gentle pleading of Antigone, however, makes them waver ;
tgt_text.1816: and the indignant protest of their suppliant, who asks bitterly if the well-known fame of Athens for succouring the stranger and oppressed is, after all, but an idle boast.
tgt_text.1819: Not surely of the man who bears it, or of any acts of his,—“a man more sinned against than sinning." "
tgt_text.1820: Whatever I have done was done unwittingly ;
tgt_text.1821: and they whom I wronged, had first wronged me,–and that with full intent."
tgt_text.1822: Eventually the Chorus are so far persuaded as to refer the matter to Theseus, whose coming is immediately expected.

tgt_text.1825: But oracles have said that the issue of the struggle rests with CEdipus ;
tgt_text.1826: and so Creon will soon arrive, in order to get possession of his person.
tgt_text.1827: The purpose of the Thebans, however, is not to reinstate their old king in the land, but to plant him somewhere on their borders, that they may be masters of his grave after his death ;
tgt_text.1828: for the oracle had also said that his tomb should confer safety on the land, in which it was situated.

tgt_text.1837: Thus CEdipus vents his indignation on his unfilial sons, while promising to confer on those, who protect him, a boon that shall serve them well for ever. (11. 310-460.)
tgt_text.1838: By the advice of the Chorus, who have been struck by what the sightless stranger has just said, CEdipus proceeds to make atonement to the Eumenides, as the deities to whom he has first come as a suppliant.
tgt_text.1839: The rites of purification are carefully described to him by the elders, and Ismene is sent to perform them for her father, whose blindness and feebleness preclude him from acting for himself.
tgt_text.1841: After Ismene's departure, the Chorus can no longer contain their curiosity, but insist on learning from CEdipus the whole story of his sad life ;
tgt_text.1842: he answers their questions, and once more protests that he was but an instrument in Fate's hands ;
tgt_text.1843: no moral guilt can be imputed to him.

tgt_text.1857: Accordingly CEdipus is received as a citizen under the protection of Athens and of the people of Colonus, more especially;
tgt_text.1858: and his fears of armed intervention from Thebes are quieted by the repeated assurances of Theseus.
tgt_text.1860: Then follows a beautiful ode, welcoming the stranger to his new home,--the most famous choral ode, perhaps, in the whole range of Greek literature,–in which the beauties and glories of Colonus, the poet's own native place, are lovingly described.
tgt_text.1862: The announcement that Creon is actually approaching throws CEdipus into a state of alarm, nor is he reassured by the cunning speech, by which Creon endeavours to justify himself and make a good impression on the Chorus.
tgt_text.1863: He first professes deep com­ passion for his unhappy kinsman, and begs him to return and hide the family reproach in the seclusion of his native city.
tgt_text.1864: But CEdipus is not to be beguiled by such smooth words.
tgt_text.1865: Thebes and Creon did nothing for him in days gone by ;
tgt_text.1866: now they offer him what he does not ask, and he knows the reason ;
tgt_text.1867: it is not to take him home they come, but to plant him on their borders, for their own selfish ends. "
tgt_text.1868: My curse upon you, one and all!" he cries, " and now get you gone ! " (11. 720-799.)
tgt_text.1869: Creon endeavours to argue with him, and, failing in this, begins to threaten.
tgt_text.1870: He now informs CEdipus that Ismene is already in his power, and at the same time orders his guards to carry off Antigone also.
tgt_text.1871: The elders of Colonus interpose, but force prevails, and she is hurried away.
tgt_text.1873: Creon is on the point of seizing CEdipus, who has cursed him for his cruelty, when Theseus hurriedly enters.
tgt_text.1874: He has heard cries for help and demands to know the reason.
tgt_text.1875: No sooner has he heard, than he despatches horsemen to overtake the Theban guards and bring back the maidens, while he sternly rebukes Creon's overbearing action, and warns him, that, until the maidens are produced again, there will be no return to Thebes for him. (1L 800-936.)
tgt_text.1876: Creon first attempts to justify his conduct, arguing that he is really doing Athens a service in removing a pollution from the land, and appealing to the wisdom of the council of Areopagus to confirm his act.
tgt_text.1877: Theseus must, of course, act as he thinks best, adds the crafty speaker, " for though my cause is just, the lack of aid makes me weak."
tgt_text.1878: At this shameless and impudent utterance, CEdipus can no longer contain himself.
tgt_text.1879: In a strain of passionate vehemence he repels Creon's taunts, defends himself from his ungenerous accusations, and proves that it is Creon who ought to be ashamed of himself for publishing the reproach of his family, far more than the unhappy victim who was but a pas­ sive instrument in the resistless hands of Fate.
tgt_text.1880: Finally he appeals to the Eumenides to help him and uphold the right.
tgt_text.1882: Theseus cuts short further recriminations by peremptorily ordering Creon to lead the way in the rescue of the maidens, at the same time warning him not to expect any assistance from possible accomplices in Athens.

tgt_text.2834: As for this fellow, had I been as angry3 as he has de- served, I had not let him go unscathed from my hand;
tgt_text.2835: but, as it is, the laws which he imported with himself, these and no others shall be used for his governance.
tgt_text.2837: Thou shalt ne'er go forth from this land till thou bring those maidens hither to me, and set them before mine eyes;
tgt_text.2838: for thy doings are a slur on me, on thy own stock, and on thy land,-thou, that hast come to a city where justice is practised and law supreme in everything;
tgt_text.2839: and, spite of that, regarding not this land's authorities, but, forcing an entry, as thou hast, art making spoil of what thou wilt, and drawing to thy side unwilling followers, deeming that mine was some city void of men or peopled with a race of slaves, and I but as a thing of nought.
tgt_text.2840: Yet 'twas not Thebes that brought thee up to be a knave ;
tgt_text.2841: for it is not her way to rear her sons in lawlessness, nor would she praise thee if she learnt that thou wert robbing me of mine, and the gods of their own, by dragging hence with violence unhappy suppliants.
tgt_text.2842: Never would I, if I set foot in thy own Thebes, drag or seize aught thence, without the ruler's will, whoe'er he were,—nay, though I had the justest plea of all;
tgt_text.2843: but I should know how it became a stranger to conduct himself amongst citizens.
tgt_text.2844: Whereas thou art bringing shame on a city that deserves it not, even on thine own, and, in thy case, increase of years is bringing age and senselessness together.
tgt_text.2845: So have I said it already, and I repeat it now;
tgt_text.2846: let some one bring the maidens hither with all speed, unless thou wouldst take up thine abode in this land by force, and not of thy free will;
tgt_text.2847: and what I tell thee, I intend, as truly as it leaves my lips.
tgt_text.2849: Stranger, dost thou see at what a pass thou art?
tgt_text.2850: For thou, though deemed to come of honest stock, art found to be an evil-doer.

tgt_text.2855: And I was sure they would not receive a man with unclean hands, a parricide, one with whom was found the unholy marriage of a mother with her child.

tgt_text.2873: And if, again, when born, poor wretch, as I was born, I met my father hand to hand and slew him, knowing nought of what I did or unto whom I did it, how couldst' thou fairly blame the deed I did not choose ?
tgt_text.2874: And of that marriage with my mother, own sister to thee as she was, art not ashamed, 0 reckless man, to wring from me what I will say anon,-for be silent I never will, when though hast gone to such impious lengths of speech.
tgt_text.2876: she was my mother,—my mother, yes, ah me !-but neither of us knew it,-and, mother of me though she was, she bare me children to her shame.

tgt_text.2878: and yet I did not wed her of my own free choice, nor speak I thus of choice.
tgt_text.2879: Nay, it is not in this marriage I shall win an evil name, nor in that slaying of my father which thou art ever flinging in my teeth with bitter taun̈ts.
tgt_text.2880: For answer me but one of all questions.

tgt_text.2882: Methinks that, as thy life is dear, thou wouldst avenge thee on thy guilty foe, nor look about to justify the act.

tgt_text.2886: It suits thee well to fawn on far-famed Theseus, and on Athens as a nobly-ordered state !
tgt_text.2887: And yet, with all this lavish praise, it doth escape thy memory, that if there is a land which knows how to give the gods their due and reverent worship, this land excels therein ;

tgt_text.3049: with that before thee, well I know thou wilt perceive how evil is the end that crowneth evil wrath;
tgt_text.3050: for no small grounds hast thou to ponder this, reft, as thou art, of the sight of thine eyes.

tgt_text.3070: What weariness is not his lot?
tgt_text.3071: Envy is, there, and faction, and strife, and battle, and bloodshed;
tgt_text.3072: and, last of all, to crown his wretched lot, comes hateful age, infirm, unfriended, shunned by all, with whom dwell all the worst of woes.
tgt_text.3073: Now this poor wretch hath reached that bourn,—not I alone;
tgt_text.3074: and as some headland, facing north, is lashed by winter's waves on every side, so too on him are waves of dire affliction dashing evermore, in furious wise;
tgt_text.3075: some from the setting of the sun, and some from his uprising, some in the path of his noontide ray, and some from the gloom of realms Rhipæan.

tgt_text.3086: Whom I have found in a strange land, an outcast here with both of you, clad in this vile raiment, whose loathly filth has made his aged frame its home, wasting the flesh it long hath grown upon;
tgt_text.3087: while o'er his eyeless head the uncombed hair waves wildly in the breeze;
tgt_text.3088: and such food as he carries, to staythe pangs of hunger, doubtless matches well therewith.

tgt_text.3090: and I testify to my own utter worthlessness in all matters affect­ ing thy livelihood;
tgt_text.3091: ask not others of my sins.

tgt_text.3098: Hast thou no answer for me ?

tgt_text.3100: Daughters of Œdipus, sisters mine, seek ye, at least, to unlock our father's lips, which will not speak nor brook ad- dress, that he send me not hence, dishonoured thus, a sup­ pliant of the god, without a word of answer !
tgt_text.3102: Tell him thyself, unhappy one, the need that brings thee here;
tgt_text.3103: for words, when there be many said, have found the dumb a tongue ere now, perchance as giving some delight, or winged maybe by rage or pity.
tgt_text.3105: Yea, speak I will,—for thy advice to me is good,­ first calling on the god himself to succour me;
tgt_text.3106: for from his altar was I raised by the ruler of this land to come hither, with leave to speak and hear, and then go safely.
tgt_text.3108: Which promise, sirs, I fain would see made good by you, and by my sisters here, and by my sire.
tgt_text.3109: Now, father, will I tell thee the reason of my coming.
tgt_text.3110: I have been driven forth into exile from my country, because, as thine elder son, I claimed to take my seat on thy sove­ reign throne.
tgt_text.3111: This was why Eteocles, albeit the younger, thrust me from the land;
tgt_text.3112: not that he had prevailed in argu­ ment or resorted to the test of actual might, but he per­ suaded the city.
tgt_text.3113: Now I hold it most likely that the fiend, who pursues thee, is the cause of this;
tgt_text.3114: further, this is what the prophets also tell me.
tgt_text.3115: For, when I came to Dorian Argos, I took to wife the daughter of Adrastus, and bound by an oath to myself all that were foremost in renown and most esteemed as warriors in Apia's 2 land, that with them I might gather the sevenfold host of spears to march to Thebes, and either die in justest cause, or cast the authors of this villainy forth from the land.
tgt_text.3117: Why have I now come hither?
tgt_text.3118: With suppliant prayers I come to thee, father, —my own prayers and the prayers of my allies, who now on every side surround the plain of Thebes with sevenfold array of spears.
tgt_text.3119: Such as are Amphiaraus, lightning-speared, first in warrior's might, and first in augur's skill;
tgt_text.3121: third comes Eteoclus, an Argive born;
tgt_text.3122: Hippomedon is fourth, whom Talaus, his father, sent;
tgt_text.3123: the fifth is Capaneus, who boasts that he will raze and waste with fire the town of Thebes;

tgt_text.3515: MESSENGER.SCENE.-Before the royal palace at Thebes.
tgt_text.3516: THE scene of the play is laid before the royal palace at Thebes, where Creon is now king after the death of CEdipus and his sons, Polyneices and Eteocles, who had disagreed as to their respective rights,—Eteocles claiming the sole sovereignty and refusing his brother a share ;
tgt_text.3517: whereupon Polyneices, who had meantime allied himself with Argos, by marrying the king's daughter, brings an army, led by himself and six other chieftains, against his native city.
tgt_text.3518: In the battle, which follows, the brothers fall by each other's hands, and the Argive host, losing its other leaders also, decamps in haste and fear by night.
tgt_text.3519: It is on the very day succeeding these momentous events that the play opens.
tgt_text.3520: Creon, the new monarch, has issued an inhuman decree, that no one, on penalty of death, shall honour Polyneices, the enemy and traitor to his country, with the rites of burial.
tgt_text.3521: His body is to lie, where it fell, a prey for dogs and carrion birds ;
tgt_text.3522: Eteocles, on the other hand, receives all honour, as the champion of Thebes, who has died in her defence.
tgt_text.3523: It is still early dawn, when Antigone appears before the palace in earnest conversation with her sister Ismene, whom she informs of Creon's decree, and invites her aid in setting it at de­ fiance by burying her brother.
tgt_text.3524: Ismene endeavours to dissuade her from the rash attempt, pointing out that such disobedience will only entail fresh suffering for them both,-and surely they have seen enough of that in their family already;
tgt_text.3525: let her re­ member her sex ;
tgt_text.3526: women must not strive with men, or subjects with their rulers ;
tgt_text.3527: and, lastly, the dead will pardon them under the circumstances.
tgt_text.3528: But Antigone rejects these timid counsels with scorn :
tgt_text.3529: she feels she owes a higher duty to her dead brother than to the self-willed tyrant;
tgt_text.3530: let Ismene go her own way and consult her safety ;
tgt_text.3531: sIte, at any rate, has resolved to do the deed, come what may.
tgt_text.3533: Antigone filled with heroic fortitude, Ismene with weak misgivings for the issue.

tgt_text.6342: CHORUS OF TRACHINIAN MAIDENS.SCENE.-Before the House of Heracles at Trachis.THE story of Heracles finds many different versions at the hands of ancient writers, and it would be difficult to say which of these Sophocles followed in the Trachiniæ,-if indeed he fol­ lowed any one definitely throughout.
tgt_text.6343: It is mainly with the closing scene of the hero's life that the poet is concerned, and with the events directly leading up to this tragic climax;
tgt_text.6344: inci­ dentally certain facts relative to his past career may be gathered, often dimly enough, from scattered hints through the play.
tgt_text.6345: Thus, for example, the winning of Deianeira from her suitor Achelous, the river-god ;
tgt_text.6346: the insult offered to the young bride at the river Evenus by the ferryman, Nessus the Centaur, with its tragic sequel;
tgt_text.6347: the visit to Eurytus at CEchalia in Eubœa, and the treacherous murder of Iphitus, the son of his host, in revenge for the father's opposition to the passion of Heracles for his daughter Iole;
tgt_text.6348: the year of bondage to Omphale in Lydia, im­ posed by Zeus as a punishment for this crime ;
tgt_text.6349: the sack of Œchalia and the capture of Iole ;
tgt_text.6350: -these, and a few allusions to the hero's labours performed for Eurystheus, king of Argos, by reason of Hera's jealousy of Alcmena's son, must be gathered here and there from the speeches and choral odes, to serve as an introduction to the play itself.
tgt_text.6351: The moment chosen by Sophocles for the opening of the play is an extremely critical one in the life of Heracles.
tgt_text.6352: An oracle had told him that, after long years of toil and suffering, an end of all his troubles should come, but what this end was to be was not further specified.
tgt_text.6353: Twelve long years of constant toil have passed ;
tgt_text.6354: each labour has been faced and surmounted ;
tgt_text.6355: and only once has the patient hero adopted unworthy means to secure his end.
tgt_text.6356: Baffled rage had led him once into an act of cruel trea­ chery ;
tgt_text.6357: and Zeus, his father, claims the penalty ;
tgt_text.6358: so for a twelve- month more he must toil in shameful servitude to a barbarian woman ;
tgt_text.6359: but the hero has brooded the while over his disgrace, and no sooner is his year of bondage over than he avenges him­ self on the ultimate cause of his affliction by sacking CEchalia and slaying Eurytus with all his race, save Iole, the maiden whose fatal beauty had first ensnared him.
tgt_text.6360: Meantime his faithful wife, Deianeira, is waiting and hoping her lord's return at Trachis, whither Heracles had removed with his family from Tiryus after the murder of Iphitus, in order to be under the protection of King Ceyx.
tgt_text.6361: It is at this point that the play opens.
tgt_text.6362: Deianeira, the lonely, patient wife, is discovered before the house of Heracles at Trachis;
tgt_text.6363: she is reviewing, partly to herself, partly to her old and trusty nurse, the troubled life she has passed, ever since the eventful day when her mighty lord saved her from her savage suitor, Achelous, and made her his own true wife.

tgt_text.8974: CHORUS OF FIFTEEN SAILORS FROM THE SHIP OF NEOPTOLEMUS.MERCHANT.HERACLES.SCENE.-A lonely spot on the coast of Lemnos.
tgt_text.8975: THE materials for his " Philoctetes " were probably drawn by Sophocles from the lost epics on the tale of Troy.
tgt_text.8976: The details of the story may be found in the " Posthomerica " of Quintus Smyrnæus, ix.
tgt_text.8977: 327 sqq.Philoctetes, the son of Pœas, had inherited the famous bow and arrows of his friend Heracles, in return for the service he did that hero in kindling his funeral pyre on Mount CEta.
tgt_text.8978: As one of the suitors of Helen, Philoctetes sailed with the other chieftains for Troy with seven ships from his native land of Malis, beneath the shadow of CEta, by the streams of Spercheius ;
tgt_text.8979: but, on the fleet stopping at Chryse, a small island near Lemnos, to sacrifice by divine command, Philoctetes was bitten in the foot by a snake, which guarded the sacred precinct of the nymph Chryse.
tgt_text.8980: His wound, seemingly incurable, caused him such awful agony and became so offensive to his comrades, that, to escape his piercing screams and the stench of his festering foot, they followed the advice of the crafty Odysseus and put him ashore, all alone, on Lemnos.
tgt_text.8981: But, in the tenth year of the siege of Troy, having learnt from their captive, the Trojan prophet Helenus, that the city could not be taken by them without the bow of Heracles being brought against it, they sent Odysseus with Neoptolemus, the son of Achilles, to Lemnos to obtain it from Philoctetes.
tgt_text.8982: It is at this point the play opens.
tgt_text.8983: Odysseus and his young comrade have landed on the desert shore of Lemnos, and Odysseus is describing the exact spot, where, in obedience to the general wish,-as he is careful to add,-he had put Philoctetes ashore ten years previously,-his presence in the Achæan host having been rendered intolerable by the effects of the snake-bite in his foot.
tgt_text.8984: Neoptolemus, being unknown to Philoctetes, who would naturally resent any advances on the part of Odysseus, is sent on by the latter to find the sufferer's cave, while Odysseus remains hidden, after posting a scout to keep watch lest Philoc­ tetes should come upon them unawares.
tgt_text.8986: Philoctetes is not there, but the evidences of his fearful malady are only too manifest.
tgt_text.8988: Odysseus then proceeds to unfold his plot for capturing Philoctetes ;
tgt_text.8989: it will be necessary, he says, to use guile ;
tgt_text.8990: Neop­ tolemus must say that he too has suffered at the hands of the Atreidæ and Odysseus, and so gain the confidence of Philoctetes the bow must be obtained somehow;
tgt_text.8991: questions of right and wrong can wait;
tgt_text.8992: everything, after all, is right which is expedient;
tgt_text.8994: Neoptolemus at first indignantly refuses to dirty his lips with a lie, but at length he is persuaded into believing that the interests of the Achæans come first;
tgt_text.8995: Troy cannot fall without the bow of Heracles, and Neoptolemus, its fated conqueror, will fail unless he can persuade Philoctetes to yield. (11. 50-134.)
tgt_text.8996: Odysseus then disappears, and Neoptolemus instructs the Chorus how they are to help him.
tgt_text.8997: Meantime, Philoctetes is heard in the distance, heralded by moans of anguish.
tgt_text.8999: Entering with slow and painful steps, he learns on inquiry who his visitors are, Neoptolemus adding that he and his men are on their way to Scyros from Troy.
tgt_text.9000: Philoctetes rejoices to find they are from Hellas ;
tgt_text.9001: but do they not know him?
tgt_text.9003: so he tells his story,-how he had been cast ashore by Odysseus, and the pitiful life he has since led on lonely Lemnos. (11. 218-316.)
tgt_text.9004: Neoptolemus expresses his compassion and says that he too has good cause to loathe Odysseus and the Atreidae for cheating him of his father's arms after entreating him to come to Troy to their aid (11. 317-377);
tgt_text.9005: indignant at this treatment, he has left Troy and is on his way home.
tgt_text.9006: The Chorus confirm this story, and Philoctetes exhibits a generous sympathy.
tgt_text.9007: Then ensues a long talk about the fate of various warriors at'
tgt_text.9009: after which Neoptolemus expresses his intention of sailing away.
tgt_text.9011: The thought of being left alone again calls forth an impassioned appeal from Philoctetes. "
tgt_text.9012: Will not Neoptolemus spare him one passing thought ?
tgt_text.9013: Has he nowhere he can stow him for the short voyage home ?
tgt_text.9014: It is not much to grant, and a good deed is its own reward."
tgt_text.9015: The Chorus add their entreaties, and Neoptolemus is on the point of consenting, when two strangers are seen approaching.
tgt_text.9017: These are a merchant,—(really an emissary of Odysseus in disguise),­ and a sailor.
tgt_text.9018: The former declares himself to be a trader between Peparethus and Troy with wine for the Achaean army;
tgt_text.9019: he has learnt something that may interest Neoptolemus, and has come out of his way to tell him that the Atreidæ have sent to bring him back by force ;
tgt_text.9020: and, further, he adds incidentally that Odysseus and Diomedes are gone in quest of Philoctetes, whose presence at Troy is necessary for their success ;
tgt_text.9021: this they have learnt from the Trojan prophet Helenus.
tgt_text.9023: After the exit of the merchant, Philoctetes is more anxious than ever to start, before Odysseus can reach Lemnos ;
tgt_text.9024: and, though Neoptolemus points out that the wind is against them, he gains his point and enters his cave to collect his few treasures.
tgt_text.9026: The Chorus meantime chant an ode on the awful sufferings of this lonely man, contrasting them with the happier life now before him (11. 676-729);
tgt_text.9027: but, before Philoctetes can start, he is attacked by a fearful paroxysm of pain ;
tgt_text.9028: unable to control himself, he implores Neoptolemus to stay by him, at the same time handing him the bow and arrows to keep till the fit is past;
tgt_text.9029: at last he falls asleep from sheer exhaustion, and the Chorus, after singing a short hymn of exquisite beauty to the god of sleep (11. 730-832), when they see him safely asleep, counsel departure without him ;
tgt_text.9030: but Neoptolemus tells them that the bow without its master is useless.
tgt_text.9032: Philoctetes awakes and thanks his watchers in pathetic language for having stayed loyally by him in his helplessness ;
tgt_text.9033: he is anxious to be going without more delay, but now it is Neoptolemus who hangs back;
tgt_text.9034: there is something on his mind;
tgt_text.9035: he parries the other's questions feebly for awhile, but finally confesses that Troy, not Scyros, is their destination.
tgt_text.9037: The despair and indignation of Philoctetes are terrible.
tgt_text.9038: To think that he has trusted this youth, who seemed so guileless, only to find himself heartlessly duped I His bow is gone ;
tgt_text.9040: Abuse, remonstrance, entreaty succeed one another,­ and not without effect.

tgt_text.10501: What, then, are we to do, if we cannot persuade thee by argument to aught that I propose ?

tgt_text.10504: Leave me to suffer this my fated lot;
tgt_text.10505: but the promise thou didst make me, with my right hand in thine, even to convey me home, I pray thee fulfil, my son, and that without delay or any further thought of Troy;
tgt_text.10506: for I have had my fill of tearful lamentation.
tgt_text.10508: If it seems good to thee, let us away.
tgt_text.10514: Aye, as firmly as I may.
tgt_text.10516: But how shall I escape the Achæans' blame ?
tgt_text.10520: What if they lay waste my country?
tgt_text.10525: One last obeisance to the land, and then away.
tgt_text.10528: Not yet, not yet, son of Poeas, till thou hast heard me speak.
tgt_text.10529: Bethink thee, 'tis the voice of Heracles thou hearest, his face thou beholdest.
tgt_text.10530: For thy sake have I left the seats of Heaven and come hither to tell thee the purposes of Zeus and so prevent the journey on which thou art starting.
tgt_text.10531: Now hear and heed my words.
tgt_text.10532: And first will I tell thee how it fared with me, ofall the labours I endured, from first to last, to win im­ mortal fame, as thine eyes now see.
tgt_text.10533: And this is thy lot too, be well assured, to make thy life a life of splendid fame through these thy sufferings.
tgt_text.10534: Thou shalt go with this man to the Trojan citadel, and there, first of all, be released of thy grievous disease, and then, being adjudged the champion of the host, thou shalt, with this bow of mine, require his life of Paris, who was the cause of these troubles ;
tgt_text.10535: and thou shalt sack Troy, and send its spoils to thy own home,—receiving from the army the meed of valiancy,—e'en to the hills of Œta, thy native land, for Poeas thy father to see.
tgt_text.10536: But of all the spoils thou gettest thyself from yonder' host, of these bring somewhat to my pyre as memorials of my bow.
tgt_text.10537: To thee, too, son of Achilles, I give this counsel j for neither canst thou conquer the land of Troy without this man nor he without thee;
tgt_text.10538: but like two lions, that seek their meat together, keep guard upon each other, thou on him and he on thee.
tgt_text.10539: And I will send Asclepius to Ilium to end thy sickness;
tgt_text.10540: for the city is doomed to be the prey of my archery a second time.
tgt_text.10542: But take good heed of this, that ye reverence what concerns the gods, what time ye ravage the land;
tgt_text.10543: for father Zeus esteems all else of less account.
tgt_text.10544: For piety dieth not 1 with men :
tgt_text.10545: whether they live or die, for it there is no death.
tgt_text.10547: 0 herald of words I have yearned to hear, appearing now at last, I will not disobey thy bidding.
tgt_text.10551: Delay not, then, for any time to act;
tgt_text.10552: for your chance presses and the fair breeze yonder behind you.
tgt_text.10554: Come, then, let me call upon this land as I am starting.
tgt_text.10555: Farewell, 0 roof that hast watched with me ;
tgt_text.10556: ye nymphs who haunt the watery meads, farewell;
tgt_text.10557: farewell, thou deep bass voice of sea-beat promontory,2 where full oft in thy deepest recess my head has been drenched by the south­ wind beating upon it, and oft has the Hermæan hill sent me back an echo to my groaning, when the tempest of anguish went o'er me.
tgt_text.10558: But now, 0 founts and Lycian spring, I am leaving, leaving you at last!
tgt_text.10559: This was a dream I ne'er indulged.
tgt_text.10560: Farewell, 0 sea-girt land of Lemnos, and waft me with fair voyage, in blameless wise, to that bourn, whither great Destiny alike is guiding me, and the advice of friends, and that all-mastering god, who hath accomplished this.
tgt_text.10562: Let us be going now, all together;
tgt_text.10563: after we have prayed to the nymphs of the sea to come and make our journey safe.

tgt_text.0: Occorre prima un dialogo fra Edipo e il sacerdote (1-84) :
tgt_text.1: il re chiede a costui qual è il motivo che egli e la gente tebana supplici in atto, con rami d’olivo in mano, si accalchino ai gradini dell’altare (forse quello di Apollo liceo);
tgt_text.2: a che gl’incensi e i pianti, dovunque per la città?
tgt_text.3: che temono o chiedono, dacché egli è pronto a soccorrerli (vv. 1-13).
tgt_text.5: Tebe è in preda a un morbo funesto, la peste, che distrugge tutto :
tgt_text.7: li soccorra il re dunque, egli che li ha soccorsi altra volta, o, altrimenti, fra breve non regnerà che sur un paese disabitato (14-57).
tgt_text.8: Se è tale, soggiunge Edipo, l’oggetto delle vostre preghiere, anch’ io ho pianto da un pezzo per il comune dolore, e finalmente non ho saputo trovare miglior rimedio che mandar mio cognato Creonte al tempio di Delfo, per sentire da Apollo come mio debba fare a salvar la città (58-77).
tgt_text.9: Intanto il sacerdote ed il re avvisano appunto l’arrivo di Creonte, lieto in sembiante (78-84).
tgt_text.10: Al dialogo fra Edipo e il sacerdote segue quello fra Edipo e Creonte (85-146).
tgt_text.11: Costui riferisce al sovrano che il responso è buono, perchè tutto sta nel punire un delitto che contamina il paese (85-98);
tgt_text.12: e, sollecitato dal re ad esser più esplicito, aggiunge che si ha da vendicar l’assassinio di Laio, predecessore di Edipo :
tgt_text.13: l’as-sassino è nel paese stesso, ma è rimasto ignoto, perchè quelli del séguito regio soccombettero tutti, tranne uno solo scappato per paura;
tgt_text.14: la ricerca del reo dovette allora cedere all’urgente bisogno di porre un riparo a più grave calamità, appunto la Sf inge (99-131).
tgt_text.15: Il re si assume l’impresa di scoprire il regicida, e vendicare il paese ed il dio;
tgt_text.16: tanto più che è proprio interesse, perchè chi uccise Laio potrebbe tentare ancora di uccidere il nuovo sovrano (132-146).
tgt_text.17: Il sacerdote, che è stato presente al dialogo fra Edipo e Creonte, si volge alla turba affidandola della promessa del principe :
tgt_text.18: che Apollo salvi Tebe e faccia cessare il flagello (147-150).I.
tgt_text.20: insinuante, tanto più che egli si reputa non già tebano, ma di Corinto (774 e segg).— Κάδμου;
tgt_text.22: non già, come vorrebbe altri, d’origine, νέα :

tgt_text.31: non punto, come vorrebbero il Hermann e qualche altro, i seggi.

tgt_text.61: Ricordiamo di nuovo che il re stesso sapeva tutto, e sarebbe poi stato curioso per un re non capire la ragione degl’incensi votivi e dei lamenti, quando ima peste fa strage nel proprio Stato :
tgt_text.62: ciò che egli vuole sapere è il motivo di quella loro visita giusto a un altare posto vicino al palazzo del re;
tgt_text.63: visita che ha tutto l’aspetto di un’istanza al principe, specie d’ Ικετεία, quale poi si rivela di fatto (31-4, 41-2).

tgt_text.202: il tempio, dentro cui stava l’ara fati-dica, si trovava in realtà presso il fiume Ismeno (Paus., IX, io, 2 e seg.), per ciò che il vate Ismeno sarebbe stato im figliuolo d’Apollo, natogli da Melia.
tgt_text.203: Ma l’Ellendt ricorda come Pausania asserisca che dei due figli nati ad Apollo da Melia, il vate sia stato un Tenero, detto Ismenio dal fiume :
tgt_text.204: ora se ciò si collega col fatto che Ismenio, non Ismeno, è detto anche da Erodoto (VIII, 134) il figlio d’Apollo e Melia, giova creder che Sofocle avesse acconciato quel nome lui o per esigenza metrica o per un mero errore mnemonico.
tgt_text.206: Fin qui il sacerdote ha reso plasticamente l’espressione dello sgomento;
tgt_text.207: il γάρ introduce le ragioni di tale sgomento, espresse anche queste per via d’imaginì :
tgt_text.208: è chiaro che egli vuol parlare alla fantasia del suo re, per commuoverlo meglio, άγαν :
tgt_text.209: notane la posizione metrica conservata dal De Spuches, e non disdegnar queste minuzie, di che in fondo componesi l’arte.— 23.

tgt_text.4124: Il primo è fra Creonte e il Coro.

tgt_text.4129: Il sovrano rimbrotta Creonte che abbia osato di venire nella propria casa, dopo di aver conspirato contro di lui:
tgt_text.4130: quale fiacchezza o stoltezza ha in esso scorto per isperar la riuscita della congiura e, scoperto, la impunità?
tgt_text.4131: come vorrà usurpare egli il trono senz’amici e denari?
tgt_text.4133: S’ingaggia allora un vivace dibattito fra Edipo, che non sa capacitarsi perchè Tiresia, pur essendo Laio stato ucciso da lungo tempo, non abbia mai detto quanto dice adesso, che ritien quindi indettatogli da Creonte;
tgt_text.4134: e Creonte, il quale, per convincerlo del contrario, gli dimostra come non avrebbe ragione alcuna d’aspirare al trono, godendone egli i vantaggi, in quanto è tenuto da Edipo eguale a luistesso e a Giocasta, e non partecipandone agli svantaggi:
tgt_text.4135: vada dunque il re stesso a Delfo a informarsi se ha detto il vero;
tgt_text.4136: e, se non lo ha detto, allora solo punisca (543-615).
tgt_text.4138: Dopo qualche altra botta e risposta fra il re, che minaccia il cognato di morte, e costui, che protesta tuttavia per la propria innocenza, il Coro annunzia la venuta di Giocasta (618-633).
tgt_text.4139: Breve dialogo fra lei, Edipo e Creonte.
tgt_text.4140: Giocasta li rimprovera entrambi di altercare, mentre la città è in lutto;
tgt_text.4141: Edipo accusa Creonte, il quale giura sempre la propria innocenza (634-648).
tgt_text.4142: Segue un quarto dialogo semilirico (κομμός) fra i precedenti ed il Coro.
tgt_text.4143: Questo impetra grazia per la vita di Creonte, e, dopo qualche resistenza, il re cede, purché colui vada in esilio (649-672).
tgt_text.4144: Mentre Creonte si apparecchia a partire, Giocasta vuol apprendere la cagion dell’alterco;
tgt_text.4145: ma il Coro esita alquanto, e però Edipo se ne duole.
tgt_text.4146: Il Coro assicura la sua fede al re (673-696).
tgt_text.4147: Giocasta insiste, ed Edipo si fa a spiegarle la calunnia insinuata contro lui da Creonte per bocca del vate;
tgt_text.4148: ma Giocasta lo consiglia a diffidare dei vaticini, e racconta come pure a Laio era stato vaticinato verrebbe egli ucciso dal figlio;
tgt_text.4149: laddove, invece, non venne ucciso che da ladroni in un trivio, e il figlio, appena nato, fu invece lui fatto uccider da Laio (697-725).
tgt_text.4150: Qualche circostanza del racconto di Giocasta conturba Edipo, che ne domanda delle altre, e da ciascuna di queste sente man mano accrescersi la spaventosa probabilità che il vaticinio sia vero:
tgt_text.4151: per accertarsene affatto, comanda sia fatto venir tosto il solo superstite dei cinque compagni di Laio, e che aveva chiesto ed ottenuto da Giocasta di esser mandato nei campi a pasturar greggi (726-768).
tgt_text.4152: Giocasta a sua volta domanda ragione del turbamento di Edipo;
tgt_text.4153: e questi le espone come egli, fuggendo da Corinto per evitare che si avverasse l’oracolo del dio, il quale gli avea predetto sarebbe egli stato l’assassino del proprio padre e il marito della propria madre, s’imbatte in un carro, e, in una rissa, ne uccide il conduttore, un vecchio che viaggiava e i compagni, in quelle circostanze appunto accennate da Giocasta:
tgt_text.4154: se il viaggiatore è Laio egli è parricida;
tgt_text.4156: Il Coro lo esorta a sperare, ed Edipo infatti attende la parola decisiva del pastore;
tgt_text.4157: il quale, conclude Giocasta, quand’ anche smentisse il suo primo racconto, cioè che abbiano ucciso Laio dei ladri, non proverebbe già del tutto la reità di Edipo (834-862).

tgt_text.6433: Non è difficile poi, chi ben consideri i tempi in cui visse Sofocle, che la voce del Coro esprima qui, come non di rado altrove, un convincimento proprio del poeta.I vv. 911-1085 costituiscono il terzo episodio, il quale si compone di tre parti:
tgt_text.6434: un’ allocuzione di Giocasta ai seniori tebani (911-923);
tgt_text.6435: un dialogo fra essa, il Coro, il messaggero e, tosto subentrandovi, Edipo {924-1072);
tgt_text.6436: un nuovo dialogo fra Edipo e il Coro (1073-1085).
tgt_text.6437: Nell’allocuzione Giocasta avverte il Coro che ella, commossa dello stato d’animo di Edipo, ha pensato di portar corone e timiami ai tempii:
tgt_text.6438: poiché ella nulla ha potuto sulla mente agitata del re, procurerà il lido Apollo uno scoglimento felice.
tgt_text.6439: Ma ecco arriva un messaggero da Corinto, il quale annunzia a Giocasta e, quindi, a Edipo, da lei fatto apposta chiamate, che il di lui padre Polibo è morto di malattia e di vecchiezza (924-963);
tgt_text.6440: Edipo vorrebbe quasi dubitar degli oracoli e di questo in ispecie;
tgt_text.6441: temeperò, non ostante Giocasta tuttavia lo rincori, che possa avverarsene la seconda parte, cioè quanto riguarda le proprie nozze incestuose con la vedova di Polibo, Merope (964-999).
tgt_text.6442: Dopo un certo esitare il nunzio, sia per confortarlo come per averne un compenso, lo assicura che Polibo non era padre di lui, e che Edipo fu già donato a Polibo da esso medesimo nunzio, il quale, pasturando nei boschi del Citerone, lo avea ricevuto, coi piedi traforati e legati, da un altro pastore al servizio di Laio (1000-1046);
tgt_text.6443: Edipo domanda notizie di un tal pastore ai seniori del Coro, che lo indirizzano a Giocasta, la quale dapprima risponde evasivamente, quindi scongiura con dolorosa agitazione l’ostinato marito a non voler proseguire più oltre in una tale ricerca, infine scappa via disperata (1047-1072).
tgt_text.6445: il Coro trae da tal subitanea dipartita argomento di grave sciagura che maturi nell’ombra;
tgt_text.6446: ma Edipo, il quale crede solo Giocasta avvilita dai bassi natali di lui, esclama che qualunque sia la sua origine, e perfin tale che Giocasta abbia ad arrossirne, egli è figliuolo della forfune, come tale, non rinuncierà a investigar da chi nacque.

tgt_text.9034: morire nessuno l’ha vista, perchè tutto a un tratto ecco irrompe Edipo, che attira a sè l’attenzione (1232-1254).
tgt_text.9035: Questi, continua il messaggero, domanda una spada e va cercando di lei, che era sua sposa e pur madre sua e dei suoi figli;
tgt_text.9036: infine, quasi guidato da un dio, si avventa alle porte, le svelle dai cardini, si precipita dentro;

tgt_text.9038: Allora il re, terribilmente ruggendo, rallenta il cappio, slega dal di lei corpo gli aurei fermagli, che ne adornavan, la veste e, orrida vista!, si dà con quelle assai volte sugli occhi (perchè non abbiano a veder più tante sofferenze e sciagure, chè troppe ne han viste), versando a fiotti lagrime e sangue :
tgt_text.9039: così entrambi han di sè fatto strazio, e dello splendore di Edipo, beato splendore d’un tempo, non restan più che lamenti, disgrazie, morte, ignominia.
tgt_text.9040: Ora il re grida che si apran le porte, che si mostri ai Tebani codestoparricida incestuoso, il quale, pronunciando empie parole e già maledetto, vuole sgombrar via dal paese;

tgt_text.9043: Nella seconda scena è prima un breve dialogo anapestico fra il Coro, che, percosso d’orrore alla vista dello infelicissimo, osa appena interrogarlo della sua nuova follia, senza osar quasi nemmen di guardarlo, e il re che prorompe in alti guai (1297-1311).
tgt_text.9044: Quindi il dialogo fra il Coro e il re diventa in parte giambico, in parte lirico :
tgt_text.9045: lamenti della sua nuova cecità e de’ suoi mali antichi, da parte del re;
tgt_text.9046: compianti da parte del Coro, che osa infin domandargli qual dio lo abbia trascinato fino a strapparsi gli occhi (1312-1328) :
tgt_text.9048: e, del resto, a che gli sarebbe più valsa la luce, se non forse a veder mali?
